text: a great fear that patients have is
either not waking up or remembering
things during the procedure I think the
number one misconception that Lee folks
may have about a new physiology is that
anesthesiologists are not physician so
there is tens of thousands of clinical
training hours and close to 14 years of
education that backs up in
anesthesiologist the second
misconception probably is that you go to
sleep manual wakeup and the
anesthesiologist actually just walk them
out in between first of all for these
fears that patients have about not
waking up or remembering things during
the procedure a lot of that stuff
actually relates to what kind of
anesthetic is being administered putting
the patient to sleep actually involves
administering a set of medications and
these medicines have to be reversed at
the very end so with general anesthesia
when a patient is put to sleep
usually they also get something called a
paralytic so that their muscles don't
react when the surgeon is doing the
surgery now the stories that you hear
about patients waking up and feeling
paralyzed and not able to move it's
possible that something like that
happens when a patient is also paralyzed
but this is usually under general
anesthesia there are methods for the
anesthesiologist to become aware that a
patient is more awake and needs to get
back to sleep they would administer more
anesthetic agents either through a gas
or through the intravenous form of
administration to get the patient to a
deeper state of anesthesia but with
general anesthesia it's actually
extremely rare for a patient to wake up
during the surgery the numbers are less
than 0.5%
you
